pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:0.4: 3. The third training rule on acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.2: At that time in Sāvatthī there was a family where both the husband and the wife had confidence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.3: They were growing in faith, but declining in wealth. Whatever food they had in the morning, they gave to the monks. Sometimes they went without food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.4: People complained and criticized the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.5: “How can the Sakyan ascetics not have a sense of moderation in receiving offerings?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.6: After giving to them, these people sometimes go without.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.7: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.9: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.10: “Monks, if a family’s faith is growing, but its wealth is declining, I allow you to designate it as ‘in training’, through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.11: And the designation should be given like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.12: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.13: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.14: Such-and-such a family is growing in faith, but declining in wealth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.15: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should designate that family as “in training”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.17: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.18: Such-and-such a family is growing in faith, but declining in wealth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.19: The Sangha designates that family as “in training”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.20: Any monk who approves of designating that family as “in training” should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.21: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.22: The Sangha designates such-and-such a family as “in training”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.23: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.24: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.25.1: ‘There are families that are designated as “in training”. If a monk eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from such a family, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.26: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing that is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:1.27: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.1: Soon afterwards there was a celebration in Sāvatthī
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.2: and people invited the monks for a meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.3: And so did the family that had been designated as in training.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.5: But knowing that the Buddha had prohibited eating staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from such a family, and being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.6: That family complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.7: “What is it with us that they don’t receive from us?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.8: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.10: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.11: “Monks, if you have been invited, I allow you to eat staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from a family designated as in training.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.12: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.13.1: ‘There are families that are designated as “in training”. If a monk, without first being invited, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from such a family, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.14: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing that is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:2.15: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.1: Soon afterwards a certain monk was associating with that family.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.2: One morning he robed up, took his bowl and robe, went to them, and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.3: Just then that monk was sick,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.4: and so they invited him to eat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.7: But knowing that the Buddha had prohibited an uninvited monk from eating staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from such a family, and being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.8: And being unable to walk for alms,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.10: He then returned to the monastery and told the monks what had happened,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.11: who in turn told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.12: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.13: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to eat staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from a family designated as in training.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.14: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.15.1: ‘There are families that are designated as “in training”. If a monk, without being sick and without first being invited, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from such a family, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:3.16: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing that is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.1: There are families that are designated as “in training”:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.2: a family designated as in training: a family in which the faith is growing but the wealth is declining. Such a family is designated as “in training” through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.6: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.10: not invited for later on the same day or for the following day, but only after entering the vicinity of the house—this is called “without being invited”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.12: invited for later on the same day or for the following day, but not after entering the vicinity of the house—this is called “invited”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.14: who is able to walk for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.16: who is unable to walk for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.18: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics—the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.20: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.21: If, without being sick and without being invited, he receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.1.22: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.1: If a family is designated as in training, and he perceives it as such, and he, without being sick and without being invited, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from that family, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.2: If a family is designated as in training, but he is unsure of it, and he, without being sick and without being invited, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from that family, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.3: If a family is designated as in training, but he does not perceive it as such, and he, without being sick and without being invited, eats staple or non-staple food after personally receiving it from that family, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.4: If he receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.5: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.6: If a family is not designated as in training, but he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.7: If a family is not designated as in training, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.2.8: If a family is not designated as in training, and he does not perceive it as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.4: if he eats the leftovers from one who has been invited or who is sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.5: if other people’s almsfood is prepared there;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.6: if they give after coming out from the house;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.7: if it is a regular meal invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.8: if it is a meal for which lots are drawn;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.9: if it is a half-monthly meal;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.10: if it is on the observance day;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.11: if it is on the day after the observance day;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.12: if the family gives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics, saying, “When there’s a reason, make use of these;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.14: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd3:4.3.15: The third training rule on acknowledgment is finished.
